annotation.TEXT: Also, for those of you who didn't know: I happen to have a very strong dislike for those electric barrier hazards. Despite being faster than they were in the original MM3, they don't seem to deal too much damage. Considering there's also a few generous health items in set spots around this stage, I don't feel bad about taking some hits to bypass them.

So then, for those of you that aren't regular viewers of my content: When it comes to these games, I usually like to get in two stages at minimum per video (at least, if I can help it - since there has been a few exceptions to this). Since Yamato Man's stage took a bit longer than I originally anticipated, it's time to basically go all out with reckless speed strategies.

The Super Slide does just that: it increases your sliding speed. It doesn't seem like much at first, but it can really help out at times (especially since speed is a key factor for getting to some of the hidden items in this game).

The grasshoppers from Bright Man's stage are an interesting addition to this level, but there's a few issues with them as well. I'm not sure why, but I encountered an instance where one of these guys never showed up at all (leaving me with no other choice but to jump to my death). I'm not sure if this can happen with all of the grasshoppers in this stage, but I'll point out the particular one that didn't show up for me when we get to it.

Yamato Man fights by using some new variations to his usual projectiles. The spears he rains down on you can be annoying at times, but he's still manageable...if you have a decent amount of health, at least (I personally blame the frog for hitting me at the last moment before the boss room).
And just like that, the intentional death never happened (score really does serve a purpose, even if it's only to get a few extra lives).

Contrary to what it looked like, that actually wasn't the Energy Balancer. Here, it's called the "EX Energy," which makes it so that weapon pick-ups give you even more ammo. It can be helpful at times (especially if you're running low on a weapon the boss happens to be weak to), but if given a choice, I'd probably take the standard Energy Balancer instead.

Apparently someone else took notice of how terrible the original Spark Shock was, because this game's version is actually pretty decent. It can now damage things instead of stunning them, and it also splits into spread-shots when it hits a surface. It's not quite as powerful as some of the other weapons, but it's definitely a step in the right direction for improving the original version of it.

Enker's pattern isn't too difficult to learn at first. What you really need to watch out for here is his damage output. Much like Knight Man, Enker can kill you off in a few hits, especially if you collide with his projectiles. Taking contact damage from him seems to be the lesser of two evils here, but either way, you're going to lose a good portion of health.
Aside from having a new sprite, Yamato Spear almost functions the same way as the original, only now it can be embedded into walls and be used as a platform (similar to the Super Arrow from MM5).

This second grasshopper (the one on the first orange pillar) is the one that pulled a disappearing act during my practice runs of this stage. I'm honestly not sure what caused this, but either way, I'm just glad it showed up during my recorded run.

Spark Man retains most of his old moves, though his larger projectile has been done away with. In its place, he now fires out a slightly smaller homing projectile (which actually deals rather sizable damage if it hits you).
And here's where my semi-reckless speed play nearly got me killed. Thankfully, I was able to salvage this derp moment (though just barely).
